name: Fernando Mendoza
summary: Fernando Mendoza (6’5/225) transferred to Indiana and delivered one of the most dominant quarterback seasons in recent college football history in 2025. He completed 70%+ of his passes for 3,535 yards and a nation-leading 41 passing touchdowns, added 6 rushing scores, and guided the Hoosiers to a perfect 16-0 record capped by a 27-21 CFP national championship win over Miami. Earned the Heisman Trophy (first in program history), Maxwell Award finalist recognition, and All-Big Ten First Team honors. Consensus QB1 on 2026 mock draft boards, Mendoza displays excellent accuracy, pocket poise, pre-snap processing, and leadership traits that position him as a high-floor franchise quarterback prospect with Day 1 starter readiness. Weaknesses include average arm strength that limits deep-ball velocity against tight coverage, and occasional sack-prone tendencies when facing pressure (though improved from prior seasons). Projects as the top overall selection in the 2026 NFL Draft with the tools to start immediately and develop into a long-term NFL starter.

name: Caleb Downs
summary: Caleb Downs (6’0/205) didn’t just play safety in 2025—he redefined the position after transferring to Ohio State, turning into a generational, scheme-proof chess piece who wrecked offenses from every angle. Elite range that covers half the field, football IQ that reads plays before they happen, bone-crushing open-field tackling, and ball-hawking instincts that produced multiple INTs/PBUs—earning Thorpe Award finalist status, unanimous All-American honors, All-Big Ten First Team, and consensus top-5 overall buzz as the undisputed DB1 of the class. A true unicorn with immediate Day 1 starter upside in single-high, two-high, box, or nickel roles, capable of flipping games with one play. Weaknesses: Over-aggressive tendencies (sells out for hits, occasional missed tackles in space); size/durability concerns against bigger tight ends and blockers in the run game; not elite top-end recovery speed vs. true burners. Still, the traits scream franchise safety—first defensive back off the board in 2026 with All-Pro ceiling written all over him.

name: Arvell Reese
summary: Arvell Reese (6’4/243) was a key starter and productive linebacker for Ohio State’s defense in 2025, playing a versatile role that included off-ball duties, edge setting, and occasional blitz packages. He recorded consistent tackle production, multiple TFLs and sacks as a pass-rush threat, and showed strong coverage skills against tight ends and running backs in man/match situations. Earned All-Big Ten recognition and received Butkus Award watch list consideration. A sideline-to-sideline athlete with good range, quickness in space, and instincts that allowed him to diagnose plays quickly and make plays on the ball. Versatile three-down traits with immediate starter upside at the next level. Weaknesses include ongoing development of stack-and-shed strength against climbing blockers and occasional over-pursuit or false steps in run fits when aggressive. Projects as a high-floor, early Day 2 selection (late 1st/early 2nd range) in the 2026 NFL Draft with the athletic profile and production to develop into a long-term starter and potential Pro Bowl contributor in schemes that utilize his range and coverage ability.

name: Jeremiyah Love
summary: Jeremiyah Love (6’0/214) straight-up detonated in 2025 as Notre Dame’s three-down supernova, morphing into the most complete, explosive, and terrifying running back prospect in the entire class. Legit 4.4 speed that turns on a dime, vision that sees lanes before they exist, velvet-soft hands (50+ catches as a receiver), and home-run burst that left secondaries in the dust—racking up 1,200+ all-purpose yards and 12+ TDs while punishing anyone who dared tackle him. A Doak Walker semifinalist with All-Independent honors, this dude is the ultimate zone-scheme cheat code: patient behind the line, decisive when the hole opens, and absolutely electric in space. He lines up in the slot, smokes linebackers on screens, catches swing passes like a WR, and turns short gains into house calls with YAC violence. Versatile modern weapon who can be your RB1, change-of-pace back, or third-down mismatch nightmare—early 2026 first-round whispers are turning into screams. Weaknesses? Pass-pro technique is still maturing (occasional whiffs against speed rushers); ball security lapses under heavy contact (a few fumbles when he’s taking big hits). But those are coachable, fixable, low-floor issues on a sky-high ceiling. The traits scream RB1 from Day 1: elite burst, vision, hands, contact balance, special-teams upside, and the kind of juice that makes defensive coordinators lose sleep. In a loaded 2026 RB class, Love is the one teams will fight over at the top of Round 1. Franchise back. Game-changer. The clear #1 RB off the board.

name: Rueben Bain
summary: Rueben Bain Jr. (6’3/275) was one of the most productive and disruptive edge rushers in college football in 2025 at Miami, recording double-digit sacks, 20+ TFLs, and consistent pressures while earning ACC Defensive Player of the Year, Nagurski Trophy finalist status, and unanimous All-American honors. He combined a powerful, explosive frame with a quick first step, violent hand usage, elite run-defense strength, and a high motor that allowed him to impact both pass and run phases. Versatile alignment options (stand-up EDGE to 5-technique) and game-wrecking ability made him a consistent matchup problem for offensive tackles. Consensus top-5 EDGE prospect on most big boards entering the 2026 NFL Draft process. Weaknesses include limited prototypical arm length and elite ankle flexibility/bend to consistently win around the corner with speed; occasional gap discipline lapses when pursuing stats aggressively. Projects as a high-floor, Day 1 starter with top-10 overall pick potential in schemes that value power and motor over pure bend.

name: Carnell Tate
summary: Carnell Tate (6’3/195) didn’t just meet expectations in 2025—he became the latest crown jewel in Ohio State’s legendary WR factory, emerging as a polished, five-star separator with elite route-running savvy, vice-like hands, and jaw-dropping body control that made him a nightmare matchup on every level. He racked up 800+ yards and 8+ touchdowns, flashing explosive deep-threat ability, red-zone dominance, and consistent big-play production that earned him All-Big Ten honors and a spot on the Biletnikoff Award watch list. A true WR1 prospect with first-round polish, smooth releases, and the contested-catch reliability scouts drool over, positioning him as a top-15 overall wideout in the loaded 2026 class. Weaknesses: Lacks elite top-end speed and burst to consistently create separation vertically; YAC elusiveness is solid but not game-breaking; can get jammed and disrupted at the line by long, physical press corners. Still, the tape screams high-floor, high-ceiling starter with WR1 traits ready to translate Day 1.

name: Jordyn Tyson
summary: Jordyn Tyson (6’2/200) transferred from Colorado to Arizona State in 2025 and quickly established himself as one of the most productive and reliable boundary receivers in the Big 12. He finished the season with over 1,000 receiving yards and 10+ touchdowns, demonstrating strong contested-catch ability (top-10 rate in the class), effective yards after catch, and physicality at the catch point that allowed him to win consistently on the perimeter. He earned All-Big 12 honors and was named a Biletnikoff Award semifinalist, showing dependable hands, route nuance, and red-zone effectiveness on back-shoulder and fade throws. A polished separator with good size and reliable production, he projects as a low-risk prospect with WR2/WR1 potential in pro schemes. Areas for development include elite top-end speed to stretch the field vertically and handling physical press coverage from longer corners at the line of scrimmage. Overall, his combination of traits, production, and consistency gives him a solid Day 2 projection (Round 2-3 range) in the 2026 NFL Draft with immediate starter upside at the next level.

name: David Bailey
summary: David Bailey (6’3/250) exploded in 2025 at Texas Tech (post-Stanford transfer), leading FBS with 13.5 sacks, 17.5 TFLs, a 93 PFF pass-rush grade (highest among EDGEs), Unanimous All-American honors, Big 12 Defensive Lineman of the Year, and a #3 ranking on Bruce Feldman’s Freaks List. Elite first-step burst, closing speed, violent hands, and relentless production make him a top-10 overall prospect (potential No. 2-3 non-QB). Explosive pass-rush specialist with three-down flashes and game-wrecking upside. Weaknesses: Poor run defense anchor (timid vs. blockers, high pad level, engulfed often); emotional control issues (past incidents) may drop stock slightly. High-upside disruptor with Day 1 impact potential in 2026.

name: Peter Woods
summary: Peter Woods (6’3/315) wasn’t just an anchor—he was the immovable force that powered Clemson’s defensive front in 2025, a true interior wrecking ball with brute power, lightning-quick snap explosion, and relentless disruptive presence that racked up multiple sacks, TFLs, and pressures while stonewalling run lanes. Earned All-ACC honors, made the Outland Trophy watch list, and consistently graded as one of the most reliable run-stuffers in the country—clogging gaps with violent hand usage, low pad level, and a high motor that wore down blockers over four quarters. A high-floor, NFL-ready 3-technique/NT hybrid with immediate rotational starter traits and the physicality to clog lanes against power schemes. Weaknesses: Pass-rush production remains limited (few counters or bend to finish rushes); occasional gap-sound lapses when he gambles for stats instead of staying disciplined; not a consistent interior penetrator against double-teams. Still, the tape screams dependable mid-round value in the 2026 draft—perfect Day 2 rotational piece with three-down upside if he refines the rush plan.

name: Keldric Faulk
summary: Keldric Faulk (6’6/285) straight-up owned Auburn’s edge in 2025, terrorizing offenses with 55+ tackles, 10+ TFLs, 7+ sacks, and suffocating run defense that earned him All-SEC honorable mention and vaulted him into top-20 overall prospect status (EDGE3-5 consensus range). A towering, violent-handed monster with a devastating bull rush, gap-clogging power, and a nonstop motor — this guy’s a versatile 5-technique/EDGE hybrid built like a brick wall with NFL starter traits already stamped on him. Three-down wrecking ball potential who can set the edge, collapse pockets, and wear down blockers. Weaknesses: Bend and speed to the corner aren’t elite; pass-rush plan is still raw with limited counters against quicker tackles; can play too high at times. Still, the floor is sky-high — a Day 1 starter with massive upside in the 2026 draft.

name: Jermod McCoy
summary: Jermod McCoy (6’0/193) locked down Tennessee’s boundary as the ultimate press-man corner in 2025, delivering a ferocious post-injury bounce-back with elite ball skills (multiple INTs/PBUs), blazing recovery speed, and punishing run support that earned him All-SEC honors, Jim Thorpe Award watch list recognition, and top-50 overall buzz. A shutdown technician with fluid hips, quick feet, route anticipation, and physicality in press coverage—his athletic fluidity and aggressive trigger make him a true CB1 candidate with Day 1 starter upside. Weaknesses: Lingering injury history (torn ACL) raises durability flags; struggles to match taller vertical threats due to limited length; can get grabby when challenged. Still, the traits scream high-ceiling starter in the 2026 draft.

name: Mansoor Delane
summary: Mansoor Delane (6’0/190) didn’t just lock down LSU’s secondary in 2025—he turned it into a no-fly zone after transferring from Virginia Tech, leading the entire SEC with 13 pass breakups, allowing a microscopic 26.7 passer rating when targeted, racking up 45 tackles, and snagging multiple INTs/PBUs that flipped games. A unanimous All-American, First-Team All-SEC selection, Jim Thorpe Award semifinalist, and consensus top-15 overall prospect (CB3-5 range), Delane is an elite press-man technician with lightning-quick feet, razor-sharp route awareness, ball-hawking instincts, and nasty physicality in run support that makes him a complete boundary nightmare. Declared early for 2026, this guy’s a shutdown corner with immediate Day 1 starter upside and the traits to become a CB1 in the NFL. Weaknesses: Size and length limit him against taller vertical threats; recovery burst can lag slightly against true elite burners who get a step. Still, the floor is sky-high—high-floor, high-ceiling CB1 potential with lockdown traits ready to translate from Week 1.

name: Makai Lemon
summary: Makai Lemon (5’11/195) emerged as USC’s primary receiving threat in 2025, leading the Trojans with 96 receptions for 1,156 yards (96.3 YPG) and 11 touchdowns while also contributing as a return specialist with multiple scores on punts and kicks. His performance earned the Fred Biletnikoff Award (first Trojan since Marqise Lee in 2012), unanimous All-American honors, and Pac-12 Offensive Player of the Year finalist status. Lemon displayed crisp route-running, reliable hands, quick acceleration after the catch, and versatility across alignments (slot, boundary, motion). He consistently generated separation underneath and intermediate, created yards after contact, and impacted games in multiple phases. Areas for development include limited height and contested-catch ability against longer corners, as well as occasional concentration drops in heavy traffic or at the high point. Overall, his production, polish, and playmaking position him as a high-upside receiver with WR1/WR2 potential in pro schemes and Day 1 starter traits in the 2026 NFL Draft.

name: Sonny Styles
summary: Sonny Styles (6’4/243) served as a three-year starter for Ohio State in 2025, transitioning from safety to linebacker and anchoring one of the nation’s top defenses. He recorded 77 tackles, 7 TFLs, 1 sack, 1 interception, 1 forced fumble, and displayed near-elite tackling efficiency (only 1 miss all season). Earned All-Big Ten honors and ranked as a top-10 overall prospect on several big boards (LB2 behind Arvell Reese in some rankings). Showed excellent 4.48 speed, smooth transitional movement, strong coverage skills (low yards per catch allowed), and sideline-to-sideline range in both run and pass phases. Versatile three-down linebacker capable of playing Mike, Will, or dime roles, with leadership traits and immediate starter upside at the next level. Weaknesses include inconsistent physicality and shedding vs. climbing blockers, occasional slow reads or false steps in run fits when aggressive, and ongoing need for added functional strength and mass to anchor against power run games. Projects as a high-floor, early Day 2 selection (late 1st/early 2nd range) in the 2026 NFL Draft with the athletic profile and production to develop into a long-term starter and potential Pro Bowl contributor.

name: Kenyon Sadiq
summary: Kenyon Sadiq (6’3/245) was Oregon’s leading pass-catcher in 2025, finishing with 51 receptions for 560 yards and 8 touchdowns while earning Big Ten Tight End of the Year, Mackey Award finalist status, and First-Team All-Big Ten honors. He was widely regarded as the TE1 in the 2026 class with top-10 overall prospect consideration on several boards. Sadiq displayed strong vertical seam ability, good leaping at the catch point, precise route-running, and versatility across alignments (in-line, slot, motion), forcing defensive coordinators to adjust coverage schemes weekly. He contributed on over 50% of snaps as a blocker, adding legitimate every-down value. Declared early for the 2026 NFL Draft following a breakout junior season. Weaknesses include inconsistent blocking technique (needs added mass and improved hand placement) and a 245-pound frame that can be overpowered by NFL-caliber power edges in the run game until further development. Overall, his receiving polish, athletic traits, and production position him as a high-upside TE with Day 1 starter potential and TE1/TE2 ceiling in pro schemes.

name: Avieon Terrell
summary: Avieon Terrell (5’11/180) didn’t just emerge in 2025—he became Clemson’s shutdown lockdown artist at boundary and nickel, rewriting the record books with a monster season: 48 tackles, 4.5 TFLs, 3 sacks, 9 PBUs, and an eye-popping 5 forced fumbles (new Clemson DB single-season record). A unanimous All-American, First-Team All-ACC standout, and Jim Thorpe Award semifinalist, the younger brother of Falcons CB A.J. Terrell flashed elite 4.39 speed, fluid hips that mirror routes, ball-hawking instincts that turn targets into turnovers, and a nose for the football that made him a turnover machine. A top-30 overall prospect (CB5-7 consensus range), he’s a versatile utility corner with Day 1 starter upside in press-man, zone, or slot schemes—high-floor, scheme-flexible talent ready to contribute immediately. Weaknesses: Undersized frame gets challenged in contested-catch situations against bigger-bodied receivers; run support downhill attack lacks consistent urgency and physicality. Still, the traits scream first-round potential in the 2026 draft—a shutdown playmaker with CB1 upside if he adds strength and polish.

name: Ty Simpson
summary: Ty Simpson (6’3/215) took over as Alabama’s starting quarterback in 2025 and delivered one of the most efficient and productive seasons in program history. He completed 68%+ of his passes for over 3,800 yards and 38 touchdowns, while adding 400+ rushing yards and 6 rushing scores. Earned All-SEC First Team honors and SEC Offensive Player of the Year finalist recognition, demonstrating strong arm strength, deep-ball accuracy, pocket poise, mobility to extend plays, and the ability to make reads under pressure. A dual-threat quarterback capable of attacking all levels of the field and leading the offense effectively. Weaknesses include occasional happy feet and hold-the-ball tendencies when facing pressure, aggressive decision-making in tight windows against elite coverage, and pre-snap processing that can lag under duress. Projects as a mid-to-late Day 2 selection (Round 2-4 range) in the 2026 NFL Draft with starter potential in schemes that utilize his arm talent and mobility, provided he refines decision-making and pocket mechanics.

name: Denzel Boston
summary: Denzel Boston (6’4/209) solidified his status as Washington’s go-to boundary X-receiver in 2025, delivering a breakout junior campaign with 62 receptions for 881 yards (14.2 avg) and 11 touchdowns—leading the Huskies in all major receiving categories despite team struggles and earning third-team All-Big Ten honors (coaches/media) plus honorable mention as a return specialist. A big-bodied, physical mismatch nightmare with elite hand strength, contested-catch prowess, and outstanding body control, he torched secondaries on jump balls, back-shoulder fades, and red-zone fades while adding explosive YAC and return ability (including a 78-yard punt return TD). Third-team All-Big Ten WR and a rising top-50 overall prospect in the 2026 class, Boston projects as a high-floor, Day 2 starter with WR2 upside in pro schemes thanks to his size-speed combo and reliable hands. Weaknesses: Not elite top-end speed or separation quickness against press coverage; occasional concentration drops in traffic; limited after-catch elusiveness vs. elite tacklers. Still, the physical tools, production, and upside scream first-round value with WR1 traits if he refines the release package and adds polish.

name: Kayden McDonald
summary: Kayden McDonald (6'3/326) wasn't just a rotational piece in 2025—he became the immovable cornerstone of Ohio State's elite defensive line, evolving into a full-time starting nose tackle who absolutely erased interior gaps with freakish brute power, explosive first-step quickness off the snap, and a relentless high motor that wore down entire offensive lines. He piled up 47 tackles, 8 TFLs, 3 sacks, and 2 forced fumbles, earning All-Big Ten honorable mention and generating top-20 overall prospect buzz (DL2-4 range) as one of the most dominant run-stuffers in the country. A massive, low-leverage frame that clogs lanes, swallows double-teams, and disrupts backfields with violent hand placement and sheer strength—this guy's a three-down interior force with the physical tools and motor to anchor any NFL front from Day 1. Weaknesses: Pass-rush arsenal remains limited (few counters or bend to finish rushes); can get a tick slow off the snap in obvious passing situations when he's not in attack mode. Still, the floor is rock-solid and the ceiling is sky-high—a dominant nose tackle difference-maker with immediate starter impact and All-Pro potential in the 2026 draft.

name: C.J. Allen
summary: CJ Allen (6’3/235) didn’t just play linebacker for Georgia in 2025—he became the explosive, sideline-to-sideline missile that defensive coordinators built entire game plans around, emerging as one of the most dynamic and versatile off-ball ’backers in the country. A former five-star recruit who lived up to the hype, Allen flashed elite range, sudden burst off the edge (multiple sacks/TFLs as a blitzer), lockdown coverage skills in man/match against TEs/RBs, and bone-crushing open-field tackling that left ball carriers seeing stars. He earned All-SEC honorable mention, Butkus Award watch list buzz, and top-30 overall prospect ranking (LB5-8 range) thanks to his athleticism, instincts, and ability to impact every phase—run fits, blitz packages, zone drops, and even nickel sub-packages. A true three-down weapon with sideline-to-sideline pursuit speed, pre-snap diagnostic quickness, and the physical tools to develop into a Pro Bowl linebacker in the NFL. Weaknesses: Still building stack/shed strength and functional power against climbing blockers; occasional over-pursuit and false steps when he gets too aggressive in run fit; needs added mass to consistently anchor vs. power run games. Still, the tape screams high-ceiling impact player in the 2026 draft—Day 2 starter upside (late 1st/early 2nd projection) as a plug-and-play Will/Mike ’backer ready to disrupt from Week 1 with All-Pro traits if he refines the run game details.

name: Kevin Concepcion
summary: Kevin Concepcion (5'11/190) didn't just redefine versatility in 2025—he turned himself into the most dangerous offensive chess piece in college football at Texas A&M, exploding for 61 receptions, 919 yards, and 9 touchdowns while claiming the Paul Hornung Award as the nation's premier all-purpose threat. An electric slot nightmare with intermediate route savvy, sudden burst to create separation underneath, and game-breaking YAC acceleration that shredded pursuit angles and turned short passes into chunk plays. Add elite return ability (multiple return TDs on punts/kicks), chain-moving reliability, and the ability to line up anywhere from the slot to motion alignments, and you have a high-floor, scheme-flexible weapon with legitimate first-round pedigree and WR2 upside in modern NFL offenses. While ball security under pressure and physicality against press coverage remain developmental focal points, the production, explosiveness, and playmaking scream immediate Day 1 impact. Concepcion enters the 2026 Draft as one of the nation's purest offensive dynamos—ready to tilt games from the jump.

name: Cashius Howell
summary: Cashius Howell (6’2/248) didn’t just play edge for Texas A&M in 2025—he became the most dominant, disruptive force on one of the SEC’s best defensive lines, turning into a game-wrecking nightmare after transferring from Bowling Green. In his lone season with the Aggies, Howell exploded with elite burst off the snap, violent hand usage, inside counters (that spin move was filthy), and relentless motor that racked up double-digit sacks, TFLs, pressures, and run-defense stops—earning unanimous All-American honors, SEC Defensive Player of the Year, and consensus top-15 overall prospect status (often EDGE1 or EDGE2 in the class). A bendy, explosive rusher with the length to stack/shed, quickness to win inside, and the power to bull through tackles, he collapsed pockets, erased running lanes, and flipped games with one-play impact—projected as a top-15 pick in the 2026 NFL Draft (Daniel Jeremiah had him at No. 15 to Tampa Bay in his first mock). Versatile enough to rush from wide-9, 5-technique, or even slide inside on sub-packages, Howell’s traits scream Day 1 starter with All-Pro ceiling. Weaknesses: Occasional high pad level vs. stronger interior blockers; pass-rush plan can be power-heavy without elite bend against quicker tackles; needs added mass for anchor strength in heavy run fronts. But the tape is undeniable—this is a franchise-altering edge rusher ready to dominate NFL offenses from Week 1 in 2026.

name: T.J. Parker
summary: T.J. Parker (6'3/265) cemented his legacy as one of the most technically sound and physically dominant edge-setters in college football during a relentless 2025 season at Clemson, finishing with 39 tackles, 9.5 TFLs, 5 sacks, and a career-defining three-sack demolition of South Carolina that earned him ACC Defensive Lineman of the Week honors and solidified his reputation as a run-game eraser. A technically advanced power-rusher with violent, active hand-fighting, explosive bull rush, and the brute strength to set the edge against double-teams, Parker consistently graded elite in run defense while flashing the power and leverage to collapse pockets when called upon. Though raw sack totals leveled off after his historic 2024 explosion, his Senior Bowl dominance—where he bullied NFL-caliber tackles—and high-floor traits made him a plug-and-play Day 1 impact player with first-round pedigree. Versatile enough to line up as a 5-technique or stand-up rusher, he's a high-motor, scheme-diverse force ready to anchor any NFL front from Week 1. Weaknesses: Pass-rush plan can be one-dimensional at times (relies heavily on power over counters); occasional high pad level vs. quicker tackles; production dipped slightly from 2024 peak. Still, the tape screams high-floor starter with All-Pro upside in the right system—top-15 pick potential in the 2026 draft.

name: Caleb Banks
summary: Caleb Banks (6'6/330) entered 2025 as one of the most physically gifted and intriguing defensive linemen in college football—a towering, explosive 3-tech/5-tech prototype with rare length, freakish burst off the snap, and the agility to flip games in both run and pass phases. Coming off a 2024 breakout (4.5 sacks, 7 TFLs), he carried preseason All-SEC hype, Chuck Bednarik and Bronko Nagurski watch list nods, and top-20/30 overall ranking as a scheme-diverse disruptor capable of collapsing pockets, shedding blocks with violent hands, and erasing gaps with his massive frame. Versatile enough to align inside or on the edge, Banks flashed the tools to become a nightmare for offensive lines—quick get-off, power to bull rush, and the lateral quickness to chase down plays in pursuit. Unfortunately, recurring foot/lower-body injuries derailed the season—he missed most of 2025 and underwent surgery after a re-aggravation—turning what could have been a dominant year into a frustrating medical red-flag chapter. Weaknesses: High pad level and leverage losses when doubled or climbed on; pass-rush technique still needs refinement (limited counters and bend); durability concerns now loom large after multiple setbacks, tanking stock on draft boards. If medicals clear and he shows full recovery in pro days/workouts, the ceiling remains massive—a high-ceiling rotational-to-starter disruptor with Round 3-5 projection (or higher) in the 2026 draft, ready to wreak havoc in any NFL front once healthy.

name: Christen Miller
summary: Christen Miller (6’4/310) is a high-floor interior cornerstone who anchored Georgia’s elite 2025 front. A violent hand-fighter with a devastating first step, Miller excels as a 3-tech/nose hybrid capable of eating double-teams or collapsing pockets with pure linear power. While his pass-rush arsenal lacks refined counters beyond the bull-rush, his low-leverage win rate against the run is NFL-ready. Despite occasional leverage losses versus quicker interior blockers, his Outland-caliber tape suggests high-end first-round value. Miller is a scheme-diverse, "plug-and-play" asset with the functional mass and motor to stabilize an NFL defensive line from Week 1.

name: Colton Hood
summary: Colton Hood (6'0/195) didn't just burst onto the scene in 2025—he detonated Tennessee's secondary after transferring from Colorado/Auburn, starting every game and turning into one of the SEC's most dominant and reliable corners. He delivered 50 tackles, 4.5 TFLs, 1 INT (a pick-six that flipped momentum), 8 PBUs, and 2 defensive touchdowns (INT return + fumble recovery), earning All-SEC Second Team (AP), Jim Thorpe Award semifinalist status, and elite coverage grades (83.3 PFF, 2nd in the SEC). A confident press-man technician with ideal length, fluid hips, 4.4 speed, sticky ball-tracking, and physicality in run support, Hood (nephew of ex-NFL CB Roderick Hood) shut down one side of the field and forced quarterbacks to look elsewhere—declaring early for 2026 after one dominant, eye-opening season. An early-round riser (late 1st/early 2nd projection) with legit CB1 upside, he's a high-floor, scheme-flexible boundary/nickel weapon ready to lock down NFL receivers from Week 1. Weaknesses: Raw technique leads to aggression penalties; tackling inconsistencies (lunges and shoulder leads instead of wrapping); zone coverage can open hips early for inside breaks. Still, the tape screams high-ceiling starter with the tools to become a shutdown force in the 2026 draft.

name: Brandon Cisse
summary: Brandon Cisse (6'0/190) didn't just emerge in 2025—he exploded onto the national scene as a first-round caliber corner at South Carolina after transferring from NC State, starting all 12 games and delivering lockdown coverage that forced quarterbacks to avoid his side entirely. Posting 27 tackles (19 solo), 1.5 TFLs, 1 INT, 1 forced fumble, and 5 PBUs, he declared early on Dec. 11 for the 2026 Draft with elite athleticism that screams NFL starter: ideal length, 4.35 blazing speed, fluid hips, lightning-quick feet, dominant press-man technique (microscopic completion % when targeted), explosive change-of-direction, and physicality that punishes receivers at the catch point. A versatile outside/nickel weapon with Day 1 starter upside, Cisse earned top CB4-8 buzz across mocks (late 1st/early 2nd from Mel Kiper, CBS, Tankathon) thanks to his shutdown traits and scheme flexibility. Weaknesses: Raw technique leads to aggression penalties; tackling inconsistencies (lunges and missed wraps in space); low career ball production (few INTs); zone coverage processing lags (opens hips early for inside breaks); injury history (forearm 2024, knee 2025) adds medical caution. Still, the ceiling is sky-high—if he polishes the details and stays healthy, he's a high-ceiling CB1 with lockdown potential ready to dominate NFL secondaries from Week 1 in the 2026 draft.

name: Chris Bell
summary: Chris Bell (6’2/220) had a strong 2025 season at Louisville before a season-ending torn ACL suffered against SMU in November, which required immediate surgery and introduced significant medical considerations for his 2026 draft process. He recorded 72 receptions for a career-high 917 yards and 6 touchdowns, earning First-Team All-ACC honors and Biletnikoff Award semifinalist recognition. A physical boundary receiver with good size, power through contact, burst after the catch, body control, and contested-catch ability, he displayed traits similar to A.J. Brown in run-after-catch situations and red-zone effectiveness, with early first-round buzz before the injury. Areas for development include route nuance, consistency in production prior to 2025, and occasional ball-security issues under contact. If recovery is full and without complications, he retains upside as a WR2/3 with starter potential in schemes that utilize his physical profile.

name: R Mason Thomas
summary: R Mason Thomas (6’4/260 est.) emerged as a disruptive edge presence for Oklahoma in 2025, contributing consistent pressure and run defense in a rotational-to-starting role within the Sooners’ front. He recorded solid production with multiple sacks, TFLs, and pressures across the season, showcasing good first-step quickness, active hand usage, and power to convert speed to power in bull rushes. Versatile alignment options (stand-up EDGE to 5-technique) and a high motor allowed him to impact both pass and run phases, earning rotational snaps in a loaded defensive line group. A developmental prospect with starter traits if he continues to add functional strength and refines technique. Weaknesses: Limited bend and corner speed limit his ability to win consistently with pure speed rush; pass-rush plan can be power-reliant with fewer counters; occasional leverage issues when pad level rises against stronger tackles; run defense physicality needs added mass to anchor reliably against doubles. Projects as a mid-to-late round rotational disruptor in the 2026 draft (Round 4-6 range) with upside to develop into a three-down contributor in the right scheme.

name: Akheem Mesidor
summary: Akheem Mesidor (6’3/280) served as a key contributor and starter on Miami’s defensive line in 2025 as a sixth-year redshirt senior, playing in 15 games and finishing with 63 tackles (38 solo), 17.5 TFLs, 12.5 sacks, 4 forced fumbles, and 4 quarterback hurries. He provided consistent interior pressure and run defense, earning first-team All-ACC recognition and solidifying his status as a productive edge rusher with good quickness, hand usage, and power for his size. Versatile alignment options (stand-up EDGE to 5-technique) and high effort allowed him to impact both pass and run phases in a loaded front. Declared for the 2026 NFL Draft. Weaknesses include a power-reliant pass-rush plan with limited counters/bend against quicker tackles, occasional leverage issues when pad level rises, and age (turns 25 in April 2026) which may factor into team evaluations. Projects as a Day 2 rotational disruptor (Round 2-4 range) with the traits to develop into a starter in schemes that utilize his size and motor.

name: Anthony Hill Jr.
summary: Anthony Hill Jr. (6’3/238) was a three-year starter and key leader for Texas in 2025, appearing in 10 games before missing the final two regular-season contests due to injury. He recorded 70 tackles (38 solo), 7.0 TFLs, 4.0 sacks, 2 interceptions (including one returned for yards), 3 forced fumbles, 1 fumble recovery, and 1 pass breakup. Earned second-team All-American honors from multiple outlets (AP, AFCA, FWAA), was a Butkus Award finalist, Chuck Bednarik Award semifinalist, and Coaches’ All-SEC Second Team selection. Showed strong range, physicality in run fits, blitzing ability, and coverage skills against tight ends/running backs. Versatile off-ball linebacker with sideline-to-sideline pursuit and instincts to diagnose plays. Weaknesses include occasional missed tackles in space, need for added functional strength against climbing blockers, and injury history impacting availability late in the season. Declared for the 2026 NFL Draft. Projects as an early Day 2 selection (late 1st/early 2nd range) with starter upside in schemes that utilize his athleticism and run/pass balance.

name: Keith Abney II
summary: Keith Abney II (6'0/190) didn't just improve in 2025—he straight-up transformed from a three-star afterthought into one of the most dominant shutdown corners in college football at Arizona State, posting 44 tackles, 12 pass breakups, 2 forced fumbles, 2 INTs (including a clutch game-sealing pick vs. West Virginia), and earning First-Team All-Big 12 honors plus first-team All-American recognition from multiple outlets. This former under-the-radar recruit led the entire FBS in coverage snaps without surrendering a single touchdown (458+ snaps of lockdown duty), flashing elite ball-tracking, lightning-quick feet, sticky man coverage, and a nose for the football that turned targets into turnovers and momentum swings. A rising mid-round prospect (first-to-third round range) with boundary and nickel versatility, he projects as a high-floor Day 1 starter with the traits to develop into a reliable CB2 or slot weapon in the NFL. Weaknesses: Lacks elite top-end speed and burst to recover against burners; struggles in contested situations vs. taller vertical threats; run support physicality and downhill urgency still need refinement. But the tape screams high-floor, scheme-flexible corner with Pro Bowl upside if he adds strength and polish—ready to contribute from Week 1 in the 2026 draft.

name: Chris Johnson
summary: Chris Johnson (6’0/185 est.) was a rotational-to-starting cornerback for San Diego State in 2025, contributing in the Aztecs’ secondary with consistent coverage snaps, physicality in press, and run-support presence. He recorded solid production in tackles, pass breakups, and limited turnovers, showing good quick feet, competitive ball skills, and instincts in zone/match situations. Johnson displayed the ability to mirror routes underneath, jam at the line, and make plays on the ball when targeted. A developmental prospect with boundary/nickel traits and the physical profile to compete for snaps early. Weaknesses include limited elite recovery speed/burst against vertical threats, occasional technique lapses in transitions (footwork or hip flips), and inconsistent tackling angles in open space. Projects as a mid-to-late Day 3 selection (Round 5-7 range) in the 2026 NFL Draft with upside as a depth corner or special teams contributor if he refines coverage details and adds strength for run support.

name: Romello Height
summary: Romello Height (6'3/250 est.) didn't just break out in 2025—he became the explosive heartbeat of Texas Tech's pass rush after a wild transfer journey (Auburn, USC, Georgia Tech → Red Raiders), nearly doubling his career pressures with 9 sacks, 10.5 TFLs, and a deep toolbox of moves that left tackles spinning (that signature spin move was filthy). Helping Texas Tech to a Big 12 title and CFP run, Height flashed elite get-off, technically advanced counters, violent hand usage, and a high-octane motor that made him a constant threat despite his compact frame. A high-motor, athletic disruptor who wins with quickness, bend flashes, and relentless pursuit—mid-round projection with legitimate rotational-to-starter upside and the traits to climb boards if he adds functional strength. Weaknesses: Undersized frame gets engulfed or pushed around in the power run game; bend and corner speed remain average against longer, quicker tackles; consistency dips when facing stronger, more physical blockers. Still, the tape screams Round 3-4 steal in the 2026 draft—a high-motor, technically savvy edge piece ready to wreak havoc as a rotational game-changer with starter potential in the right scheme.

name: L.T. Overton
summary: L.T. Overton (6'5/278) didn't just anchor Alabama's defensive line in 2025—he became the ultimate Swiss Army knife, a versatile EDGE/DL monster who could line up anywhere from 5-technique to stand-up rusher and wreak havoc across alignments. Posting career totals of 132 tackles, 7 sacks, and elite run-defense grades that consistently shut down interior gaps, he earned All-SEC buzz, top-50 overall prospect ranking (EDGE9 range), and the reputation as one of the most scheme-diverse linemen in the country. A rare size-speed combo with violent power push, active hand usage, and the motor to play heavy snaps without fading—high-floor traits that scream immediate NFL starter upside in any front. Whether setting the edge against the run, collapsing pockets with bull rushes, or dropping into coverage flashes, Overton's multi-alignment value and physical tools make him a plug-and-play difference-maker. Weaknesses: Average hand accuracy and pass-rush counters limit his ability to finish rushes consistently; high pad level can be exploited by quicker tackles; get-off in obvious pass situations remains inconsistent and needs refinement. Still, the tape screams Day 2 steal in the 2026 draft—a rotational-to-starter disruptor with the frame, power, and versatility to grow into a three-down force and eventual anchor for any NFL defensive line.

name: Kamari Ramsey
summary: Kamari Ramsey (6'0/204) didn't just solidify his status as one of the nation's top safeties in 2025—he became USC's defensive quarterback and the ultimate chess piece in the secondary, returning for his redshirt junior year to deliver an elite, multi-faceted campaign that earned All-Big Ten honors and consensus top-50 overall prospect buzz. Posting lockdown coverage (absurdly low YPC allowed), multiple INTs/PBUs, and a quick-trigger downhill mentality, Ramsey showcased rare versatility—seamless in single-high, box, nickel, or man-match roles against TEs/slots—with instinctive processing, pursuit speed that closes like a missile, and leadership that set the tone for USC's back seven. A high-IQ processor who reads offenses pre-snap, anticipates routes, and flips momentum with ball disruption, his Senior Bowl invite and film scream Day 2 starter upside with the traits to develop into a Pro Bowl safety in the right scheme. Weaknesses: Tackling technique inconsistencies (lunges and missed tackles in transition); limited elite recovery speed/burst against true burners who get a step; occasional over-aggressiveness leads to penalties or blown assignments when he sells out too hard. Still, the tape and intangibles make him a high-floor, high-ceiling chess piece ready to contribute from Week 1 in the 2026 draft—a versatile, instinctive safety with franchise traits if he refines the details.

name: Dillon Thieneman
summary: Dillon Thieneman (6'0/205) didn't just star in 2025 at Oregon—he became the defensive heartbeat of the Ducks after transferring from Purdue, building on his historic freshman campaign (74 solo tackles, 6 INTs, FWAA Freshman of the Year) into a full-blown star safety with elite range that covered half the field, punishing tackling technique that left ball carriers seeing stars, razor-sharp instincts, and leadership that elevated the entire secondary. Earning All-Big Ten honors and consensus top-50 overall buzz (S top-5 range), Thieneman is a versatile single-high/box chess piece with ball skills, 4.35 pursuit speed, pre-snap recognition, and the kind of scheme fit that makes coordinators drool—capable of erasing deep threats, triggering downhill in the run game, and flipping field position with turnovers. A high-motor, high-IQ defender with Day 2 starter upside and the traits to develop into a Pro Bowl safety in the right system. Weaknesses: Occasional tackling consistency lapses in space (lunges instead of wrapping); coverage can be tested by elite vertical threats who stretch him deep; physicality and shedding need refinement against bigger blockers. Still, the tape screams high-floor, high-ceiling safety ready to contribute from Week 1 in the 2026 draft—a ball-hawking leader with franchise traits if he polishes the details.

name: Germie Bernard
summary: Germie Bernard (6’0/195) led Alabama’s receiving group in 2025 after transferring in, finishing with 64 receptions for 862 yards and 7 touchdowns, while adding 18 rushes for 101 yards and 2 scores. His performance earned Biletnikoff Award semifinalist recognition and All-SEC honors. Bernard showed strong route-running technique, reliable separation in the short-to-intermediate areas, effective yards after catch on slants and screens, and consistent hands/body control in traffic. He aligned in the slot and outside, with motion and jet-sweep usage adding versatility. A dependable chain-mover with good football IQ and low-risk traits, he projects as a rotational contributor with WR3/WR4 upside in pro schemes. Weaknesses include limited top-end speed and explosiveness to stretch the field vertically, inconsistency against physical press coverage at the line, and a modest deep-threat profile against off-coverage looks. Overall, his production and skill set position him as a Day 3 selection (Round 4-6 range) in the 2026 NFL Draft with the reliability to earn immediate rotational snaps as a slot or outside piece.

name: Emmanuel McNeil-Warren
summary: Emmanuel McNeil-Warren (6’2/202) is a violent, downhill safety who became a MAC legend before testing his mettle at Toledo. A forced-fumble machine with 9 career punches, he recorded 77 tackles and 2 interceptions in 2025. Scouts rave about his "alley-filling" aggression and elite recovery speed in the box. While his "gambler’s mentality" leads to occasional cutback lapses and coverage over-commitments, his frame and functional play-strength suggest a Day 2 ceiling. McNeil-Warren is a high-motor, scheme-versatile thumper. He projects as a tone-setting box safety with the physical tools to anchor an NFL special teams unit immediately.

name: Lee Hunter
summary: Lee Hunter (6’4/330) is a massive, nimble-footed interior force who capped a dominant career with an All-American 2025 season at Texas Tech. Recording 42 tackles and 11.0 TFLs, Hunter proved he is more than just a gap-clogger, flashing a "second gear" in pursuit rarely seen at 330 pounds. His elite upper-body strength creates instant knock-back, though his first step can fluctuate between explosive and sluggish. Despite questions regarding his three-down stamina, his ability to command double-teams and win laterally makes him a primary Day 2 target. Hunter is a "plug-and-play" nose tackle with Pro Bowl-caliber power.

name: Joshua Josephs
summary: Joshua Josephs (6’3/240) emerged as a premiere speed-rusher during Tennessee’s relentless 2025 defensive campaign. Possessing elite length and "bendy" athleticism, Josephs uses a violent bull-rush to collapse pockets against heavier tackles. Though slightly undersized for a traditional 4-3 end, his ability to set the edge and shed blocks makes him a schematic gem for odd-front teams. While he lacks the elite corner-turning bend of a top-5 pick, his agility and high-effort pursuit solidify an early Day 2 projection. Josephs is a high-floor, rotational edge with the twitchy traits to develop into a consistent NFL starter.

name: Chris Brazzell
summary: Chris Brazzell II (6’5/200) solidified his first-round buzz with a 1,017-yard, 9-touchdown breakout for Tennessee in 2025. A long-striding "split-end" with pro bloodlines, Brazzell tracks the deep ball with rare adjustment skills for his size. Despite a limited route tree in the Vols’ vertical-heavy system, his 3.2% drop rate and massive catch radius make him a nightmare in contested situations. While he needs added functional mass to defeat physical NFL press, his "gliding" speed and red-zone utility are undeniable. Brazzell is a unique, high-ceiling weapon with the tools to become a primary vertical threat in 2026.

name: D'angelo Ponds
summary: D'Angelo Ponds (5'9/170) didn't just contribute to Indiana's magical 2025 natty run—he became the fiery, ultra-competitive heartbeat of their secondary after transferring from JMU, turning into a shutdown nickel/slot menace who flipped games with pure ball disruption and fearless playmaking. Earning second-team AP All-American honors, two-time All-Big Ten recognition, and defensive MVP of both the Rose and Peach Bowls, Ponds posted a career 169 tackles, 10.5 TFLs, 7 INTs (including a pick-six on the very first play vs. Oregon), and 33 PBUs that terrorized quarterbacks. A track-background speedster with elite quick feet, razor-sharp zone awareness, closing burst, and a nose for the football that forced turnovers and momentum swings, he was Mel Kiper's CB5 and declared early on Jan. 23, 2026. Undersized frame be damned—his competitive fire, ball skills, and nickel/slot versatility scream mid-round riser (Round 3-4 projection) with legitimate Day 1 starter upside as a slot weapon or boundary backup. Weaknesses: Shorter arms and 170-pound frame limit him against taller, physical X receivers in contested situations; run-support physicality needs added strength to consistently shed blocks; occasional gambler tendencies in coverage can lead to big plays when he bites on double moves. Still, the tape screams high-ceiling nickel/slot star in the 2026 draft—ready to lock down slots, create turnovers, and thrive in modern NFL sub-packages from Week 1.

name: Jake Golday
summary: Jake Golday (6’4/240) is a high-IQ, "hair-on-fire" linebacker who blossomed into a First Team All-Big 12 anchor at Cincinnati. A Central Arkansas transfer, Golday’s 2025 campaign featured 105 tackles and 3.5 sacks, showcasing an elite downhill trigger and reliable "stack-and-shed" ability. His "tree-like" length and 4.50-speed projection make him a rare coverage asset against modern tight ends. While scouts note occasional lateral stiffness in space, his 10.5% missed-tackle rate and leadership traits scream NFL starter. Projected as a Day 2 value, Golday is a "plug-and-play" inside hammer with the frame to dominate pro-run schemes immediately.

name: A.J. Haulcy
summary: A.J. Haulcy (6'0/210) didn't just anchor LSU's secondary in 2025—he became the heartbeat of a reloaded Tigers defense after transferring in, delivering a breakout campaign filled with career-high moments: 13 tackles in a monster game against Ole Miss, game-changing INTs (including a momentum-swinging pick vs. Florida), and elite tackling/instincts that earned him universal praise as the ultimate box safety and locker-room leader. A true transfer success story, Haulcy brought downhill trigger, pre-snap recognition, and the kind of aggressive, physical presence that cleaned up messes in the run game and turned short zones into no-man's land. His football IQ, closing speed, and ability to diagnose plays before they develop made him a reliable chess piece in Brian Kelly's scheme—consistently in the right spot, making the right play, and setting the tone for LSU's back seven. Weaknesses: Coverage range can be limited against true deep threats who stretch the field vertically; run-support physicality still needs polish to consistently shed blocks and finish tackles in space; occasional over-aggressiveness leads to missed assignments or penalties when he sells out too hard. Still, the tape screams late-round/UDFA steal in the 2026 draft—a high-floor depth piece with special teams value and the upside to carve out a rotational box safety role if he adds strength, refines his angles, and proves his range in workouts. A gritty, instinctive safety ready to contribute from Day 1.

name: Max Klare
summary: Max Klare (6’5/243) is an explosive, vertical-threat tight end who solidified his stock during Ohio State’s high-octane 2025 campaign. A nuanced route runner with elite burst, Klare excels at manipulating stems to stress second-level defenders. His "catch-to-attack" mentality allows him to accelerate immediately after the catch, turning intermediate gains into chunk plays. While his functional strength restricts his effectiveness as an in-line blocker—leading to occasional leverage losses—his vision and reliable hands make him a premiere "Big Slot" weapon. A projected late Day 2 value, Klare is a scheme-versatile playmaker with legitimate high-ceiling potential as a pro.

name: Elijah Sarratt
summary: Elijah Sarratt (6’2/213) is a physical, high-IQ possession receiver who spearheaded Indiana’s 2025 national title run. A "quarterback’s best friend," Sarratt led the Big Ten with 15 touchdowns, thriving in high-leverage contested-catch situations. While he lacks elite vertical burners, his "Keenan Allen-style" savvy and refined releases allow him to consistently dismantle press coverage. Scouts prioritize his strong hands and elite ball-tracking over raw speed, projecting him as a Day 2 starter with WR2 upside. A gritty, scheme-diverse chain-mover, Sarratt is the quintessential "see-ball, get-ball" weapon ready to stabilize an NFL receiving corps from Week 1.

name: Zion Young
summary: Zion Young (6'6/265) didn't just dominate Missouri's edge in 2025—he became the physical embodiment of a modern NFL EDGE prototype, finishing his college career with 131 tackles, 11.5 sacks, and suffocating run defense that consistently graded him as one of the SEC's most reliable gap-cloggers and pocket-pushers. All-SEC honorable mention, top-50 overall prospect buzz (EDGE10 range), and a massive, long-armed frame that creates violent pocket collapse, devastating hand usage, and the kind of power that swallows double-teams and erases running lanes. A high-motor, versatile 5-technique/EDGE hybrid who can stand up, rush from a wide-9, or anchor inside—starter upside with the raw traits to develop into a three-down force at the next level. Weaknesses: Average first-step get-off and burst limit his ability to win with pure speed; aggression sometimes leads to penalties (taunting flags) and discipline issues; off-field concerns (past misdemeanor/DWI) could slide his stock on draft boards to Round 2-3 territory despite the tape. Still, when the motor runs hot, he's a rotational-to-starter disruptor with massive upside in the 2026 draft—plug him in, watch him eat.

name: Ja'Kobi Lane
summary: Ja’Kobi Lane (6’4/200) is a towering, "above-the-rim" wideout who solidified his stock as a premier boundary mismatch during USC’s 2025 campaign. Despite missing time with a mid-season foot injury, Lane posted 49 catches for 745 yards, showcasing the elite body control and "basketball-style" high-pointing that made him a Las Vegas Bowl MVP. While scouts question his top-end separation speed and thin frame against physical NFL press, his massive catch radius and 18 career touchdowns suggest high-end red-zone utility. A projected Day 2 riser, Lane offers a Drake London-esque ceiling for teams seeking a true jump-ball specialist.

name: Gabe Jacas
summary: Gabe Jacas (6'3/275) didn't just continue his rise in 2025—he became Illinois' undisputed defensive cornerstone and one of the most feared edge/linebacker hybrids in the Big Ten, exploding for 42 tackles, 11 sacks, 3 forced fumbles, and a relentless motor that terrorized quarterbacks and running backs alike. A preseason darling as one of the conference's premier pass rushers, Jacas backed it up with violent hand usage, explosive power, sideline-to-sideline range, razor-sharp instincts, and a wrestling background that turned block-shedding into an art form. His ability to set the edge, bull rush tackles, and drop into coverage made him a true three-down menace and vocal leader who elevated the entire Illinois front. Versatile enough to stand up, rush from a 5-technique, or play off-ball in sub-packages, he's a high-motor disruptor with Day 2 upside and the raw tools to develop into a rotational-to-starter NFL edge piece. Weaknesses: Hip stiffness can limit fluidity in coverage transitions; length limitations make it tough to disengage vs. longer tackles; consistency dipped after a massive sophomore leap, with occasional technique lapses under pressure. Still, the tape screams mid-to-late round steal in the 2026 draft—a powerful, instinctive hybrid ready to wreak havoc as a rotational game-changer with starter potential if he refines the bend and coverage polish.

name: Deontae Lawson
summary: Deontae Lawson (6'2/228) didn't just lead Alabama's defense in 2025—he became the commanding heartbeat and vocal soul of one of the most feared units in college football, captaining the Crimson Tide with elite pre-snap diagnostic genius, downhill violence that punished ball carriers, and rare coverage versatility that allowed him to lock up tight ends and running backs in man. Posting massive tackle totals (building on 67+ prior with even more elevated production), he racked up stops in every phase while earning Butkus Award nomination, All-SEC honors, and consensus top-50 overall buzz (LB top-5 range). A true Mike linebacker prototype with sideline-to-sideline range, tackling radius that swallows space, and leadership that elevated the entire front seven—immediate NFL starter upside with Pro Bowl potential written all over him. Weaknesses: Needs added mass and functional strength to consistently stack/shed vs. power run games; lower-body injury history raises legitimate durability flags; occasional over-aggressiveness leads to missed assignments or penalties when he sells out too hard. Still, the tape screams high-floor, high-ceiling impact player in the 2026 draft—late 1st/early 2nd-round projection as a plug-and-play Mike 'backer ready to anchor any NFL defense from Day 1.

name: Jaishawn Barham
summary: Jaishawn Barham (6’3/248) solidified his first-round trajectory after a dominant Senior Bowl week, where he showcased elite "stack-and-shed" technique during team drills. A violent, multi-role disruptor who transitioned to a hybrid edge role at Michigan, Barham’s diagnostic instincts and massive frame make him a scheme-proof asset for NFL front sevens. While his long-speed remains a talking point for vertical coverage, his ability to anchor the line and collapse pockets with linear power is unmatched in this class. A projected Day 1 selection, Barham is a high-floor "plug-and-play" defender with immediate All-Pro potential in 2026.

name: Zachariah Branch
summary: Zachariah Branch (5’10/180) silenced critics in Mobile, using his "Tyreek-esque" acceleration to consistently erase pursuit angles during one-on-one periods. The Georgia standout proved his 4.3-speed translates to refined route-running, shaking elite corners with sudden, low-center-of-gravity breaks. While durability concerns linger due to his diminutive frame, Branch’s reliable hands and game-breaking return ability solidify a fringe-first-round grade. Whether deployed as a vertical seam-stretcher or a designed-touch weapon, Branch offers legitimate "home-run" utility in creative pro schemes. A high-ceiling playmaker, he is the premier offensive spark-plug of the 2026 class ready for Week 1.

name: Omar Cooper Jr.
summary: Omar Cooper Jr. (6’0/204) is a "YAC god" whose stock exploded following his game-winning, toe-tap touchdown against Penn State. Primarily a slot weapon in 2025, Cooper led the Big Ten in yards per catch, running with the balance of a running back and forcing a missed-tackle rate of 30%. While scouts at the Senior Bowl noted a relatively limited route tree, his 4.50-speed and "attack" mentality at the catch point suggest a Rashee Rice ceiling. Cooper is a dual-threat weapon with high-end WR2 upside, especially for creative offenses that prioritize yards after the catch.

name: Jadarian Price
summary: Jadarian Price (5’11/209) served as Notre Dame’s primary complementary running back in 2025 behind Jeremiyah Love, finishing with 113 carries for 674 yards (6.0 YPC) and 11 rushing touchdowns, while adding receiving production and significant impact as a kick returner (multiple 100+ yard returns, FBS-leading ~37.5 YPR, tied for second all-time in Notre Dame kickoff return touchdowns). Earned All-American recognition as an all-purpose threat and declared early for the 2026 NFL Draft on Dec. 17, 2025. Price demonstrated elite vision in finding cutback lanes, sudden burst through holes, patience to let blocks develop, effective yards after contact, and strong special-teams value. Mel Kiper ranked him RB2 entering the process, with top-80 overall big board placement and Day 2 projection (Round 2-3 range). Low-mileage legs (freshman Achilles tear) and versatility position him well for committee or change-of-pace roles. Weaknesses include limited career volume as a complementary back, ball-security concerns (3 fumbles in 2025), developing pass-protection technique against blitzers, and lack of true power to consistently handle loaded boxes. Overall, his explosiveness, vision, and multi-phase production give him immediate-impact upside as a dynamic RB2 in the NFL with starter potential in the right scheme.

name: Eli Stowers
summary: Eli Stowers (6’4/235) is a former quarterback turned Mackey Award winner who redefined Vanderbilt’s offense in 2025. Leading all tight ends with 769 receiving yards, Stowers is a "Big Slot" specialist with wideout-level movement skills and elite ball-tracking. While his in-line anchor strength remains a developmental hurdle, his 6.1 YAC-per-reception average and route savvy make him a nightmare for traditional linebackers. After a refined Senior Bowl week where he proved his reliability as a red-zone target, Stowers’ stock is firmly in the mid-Day 2 range. He is a high-upside "F" weapon for pass-heavy pro schemes.

name: Julian Neal
summary: Julian Neal (6’2/205) is a physical, long-limbed boundary corner who used the Shrine Bowl to cement his status as a fast-riser. A former Arkansas standout, Neal excels in press-man coverage, using "violent" jams to disrupt timing at the line of scrimmage. While scouts note he can be overly aggressive, leading to occasional vertical lapses, his 83.2 PFF coverage grade and "plus" run support make him a scheme-diverse asset. Projected as a high Day 3 or fringe Day 2 value, Neal possesses the rare frame and competitive "alpha" mentality required to neutralize physical NFL receivers.

name: Chandler Rivers
summary: Chandler Rivers (5’10/188) is a technician who capped a stellar Duke career with First Team All-ACC honors. Despite size limitations, Rivers is a "total package" defender with elite recovery speed and a knack for high-pointing the football. His 2025 tape is littered with instinctive PBUs and a blocked punt, highlighting his "whistle-to-whistle" motor. While physical receivers can occasionally out-muscle him at the catch point, his refined footwork and Special Teams utility solidify a third-round projection. Rivers is a high-floor, "plug-and-play" nickel corner with the short-area burst to dominate the slot in a pro system.

name: Dani Dennis-Sutton
summary: Dani Dennis-Sutton (6’5/268) was the "physical specimen" of Senior Bowl week, measuring in with NFL-ready mass and length. The Penn State product is a disciplined edge-setter with a devastating bull-rush that routinely collapses pockets. While he lacks the "elite" first-step twitch of a top-five selection, his violent hand usage and relentless motor allow him to win through contact. Scouts have lauded his character and high football IQ, projecting him as a Late Day 1 or Early Day 2 pick. Dennis-Sutton is a high-floor base end with the functional power to start from Week 1.

name: Malik Muhammad
summary: Malik Muhammad (6’0/188) is a fluid, ball-hawking technician who spearheaded the Texas secondary before declaring as a junior. An All-SEC selection with a "stickiness" in man coverage that frustrates elite wideouts, Muhammad excels at pattern-matching and closing windows. While he needs to add functional mass to consistently reroute physical pros, his recovery speed and natural instincts are among the best in the 2026 class. Currently trending as a consensus top-50 pick, Muhammad is a high-IQ corner with the versatility to play multiple roles. He projects as a future NFL starter with Pro Bowl ceiling.

name: Darrell Jackson Jr.
summary: Darrell Jackson Jr. (6’5/330) is a "mountain of a man" who dominated the Shrine Bowl with 35-inch arms and pure linear power. The Florida State nose tackle is a gap-eater who commands double-teams, allowing linebackers to flow freely. While he isn't a "flashy" pass-rusher, his ability to "forklift" interior linemen off their spots creates consistent chaos. Scouts noted his improved conditioning in Frisco, solidifying a Day 2 grade as a premier run-stuffer. Jackson is a scheme-proof interior anchor with the "dirty work" mentality required to stabilize an NFL defensive line immediately.

name: Will Lee III
summary: Will Lee III (6’3/192), known as "The Blanket," used a standout Senior Bowl performance to prove his 54% allowed catch rate wasn't a fluke. The Texas A&M star is an exceptional accelerator who stays low in transitions, effortlessly mirroring shifty receivers. With a rare blend of height and "click-and-close" agility, Lee excels in both press-bail and man-to-man duties. While his 11.6% missed-tackle rate is a minor blemish, his ball-tracking skills and length make him a nightmare for vertical offenses. Projected in the second round, Lee is a high-ceiling corner with Day 1 starting traits.

name: Dontay Corleone
summary: Dontay Corleone (6'1/335) didn't just anchor Cincinnati's interior in 2025—he embodied the nickname "The Godfather," serving as the four-year contributor and three-year starting nose tackle who became the unmovable force in the Bearcats' front. Posting career totals of 123 tackles and 9.5 sacks, Corleone dominated with elite run-stuffing power, violent low pad level, surprising quickness off the snap for his massive frame, and gap-merchant disruption that swallowed double-teams and erased running lanes. Preseason All-American buzz followed him into the year as a high-floor NT with legitimate multi-alignment value—capable of clogging the A-gap, shifting to 3-tech, or even flashing bull-rush pocket push. A true space-eater with the strength to anchor against power schemes and the motor to play heavy snaps without fading, he declared for the 2026 draft as one of the most dependable interior anchors in the class. Weaknesses: Pass-rush consistency and stamina remain limited (few counters beyond power, tires late in long drives); leverage losses when pad level rises against quicker interior linemen; developmental as a pure 3-tech penetrator until he refines hand usage and bend. Still, the tape screams mid-round steal (Round 2-4 projection)—a versatile, powerful anchor ready to plug in as a rotational-to-starter Day 1 force with the physical tools to grow into a dominant NFL nose tackle.

name: Michael Trigg
summary: Michael Trigg (6’4/240) is a high-ceiling move-TE who rejuvenated his stock during a 694-yard, 6-touchdown breakout at Baylor. A former two-sport star at USC and Ole Miss, Trigg’s "above-the-rim" catch radius and basketball-inspired body control make him a red-zone mismatch. While scouts noted inconsistent effort in blocking drills during Senior Bowl week, his elite testing projections and ability to "Moss" defenders in contested situations solidify a mid-Day 2 grade. If he maintains focus, Trigg offers a Pro Bowl ceiling as a vertical seam-stretcher. He is the draft's premier "Big Slot" weapon.

name: Emmett Johnson
summary: Emmett Johnson (5’11/200) is an instinctive, high-motor back who spearheaded Nebraska’s 2025 offense with 1,451 rushing yards and 12 touchdowns. A consensus First Team All-American, Johnson combines elite vision with a 46-reception floor, proving he is a true three-down threat in any scheme. While he lacks "top-end" home-run speed—leading to some Day 2 slotting concerns—his 68 forced missed tackles highlight elite contact balance. Scouts view him as a "Travis Etienne-lite" prospect with the functional mass to handle pro workloads. Johnson is a "plug-and-play" RB2 with immediate high-leverage rotational value in 2026.

name: Malachi Fields
summary: Malachi Fields (6’4/223) is the biggest winner of the 2026 draft cycle, vaulting into first-round consideration after a "dominant" Senior Bowl performance. The Notre Dame transfer utilized his massive frame and "it’s mine" mentality to bully elite corners during one-on-ones in Mobile. With 17.5 yards per reception in 2025, Fields proved he is more than just a possession threat, showcasing the vertical speed to stack defenders. While he needs to refine his route-tree nuances, his elite catch radius and blocking prowess make him a Day 1 starter. Fields is the prototype boundary weapon.

name: Tyreak Sapp
summary: Tyreak Sapp (6’5/265) dominated Florida’s edge in 2025—servings a relentless, high-motor disruptor that offenses dreaded lining up against, turning into a nightmare 5-technique/EDGE hybrid who consistently wrecked plays with explosive get-off, violent hand usage, and gap-penetrating power that erased running lanes and collapsed pockets. Posting 8 sacks, 12 TFLs, and elite run-defense grades, Sapp earned All-SEC honorable mention and surged into mid-round prospect status (EDGE15-20 consensus range) as one of the most productive and athletic big men on the edge in the SEC. Long levers that create leverage nightmares for tackles, sudden first-step burst, and a nonstop motor that wears down blockers over four quarters—he’s a versatile force capable of anchoring the edge, rushing from wide alignments, or even sliding inside on sub-packages. High-motor traits and physical tools scream rotational-to-starter upside with the potential to climb boards if he refines his rush plan. Weaknesses: Average bend and corner speed limit his ability to win with pure speed against quicker tackles; pass-rush counters remain raw and one-dimensional; occasional high pad level can be exploited by savvy linemen. Still, the tape and production make him a high-ceiling Day 2 steal in the 2026 draft—Round 3-5 projection as a powerful, disruptive rotational piece ready to contribute from Week 1 with starter potential in the right scheme.

name: Garrett Nussmeier
summary: Garrett Nussmeier (6’4/215) took over as LSU’s starting quarterback in 2025 and delivered a highly productive season, completing over 65% of his passes for 3,500+ yards and 30+ touchdowns while showing strong arm talent, quick release, and the ability to make accurate throws across the field. He demonstrated good pocket presence, solid pre-snap processing, and the mobility to extend plays when needed, helping the Tigers remain competitive in the SEC. Earned All-SEC honorable mention recognition and positioned himself as a Day 2 quarterback prospect entering the 2026 NFL Draft process. Nussmeier displayed the arm strength to hit intermediate and deep windows, good ball placement on timing routes, and leadership traits in the huddle. Weaknesses include occasional inconsistent decision-making under pressure (forces throws into tight coverage), average deep-ball velocity against elite secondaries, and pre-snap reads that can lag versus complex blitz packages. Projects as a mid-to-late Day 2 selection (Round 3-5 range) in the 2026 NFL Draft with the tools to compete for a backup role early and develop into a potential starter in pro-style offenses if he refines processing and pressure management.

name: Carson Beck
summary: Carson Beck (6’4/220) transferred to Miami in January 2025 following a UCL injury that ended his Georgia tenure and immediately became the Hurricanes’ starting quarterback. In his lone season with Miami, he completed 72.4% of his passes for a career-high 3,813 yards and 30 touchdowns against 12 interceptions, while adding 43 rushing yards and 2 rushing scores. He guided the team to the CFP national championship game (a 27-21 loss to Indiana) and earned third-team All-ACC honors. Beck showed strong pocket presence, quick release, accurate timing-route throws, arm strength to access all levels, and solid pre-snap processing. A high-floor pocket passer with starter traits in pro-style offenses. Weaknesses include inconsistency under pressure (gunslinger tendencies leading to turnovers and risky decisions), average deep-ball velocity against tight coverage, occasional processing lags versus complex blitzes, and prior UCL/elbow injury history that requires medical evaluation. Projects as a mid-to-late Day 2 selection (Round 2-4 range) in the 2026 NFL Draft with the polish and arm talent to compete for a starting role if decision-making and health concerns are addressed.

name: Genesis Smith
summary: Genesis Smith (6’2/204) functions as a high-IQ post safety who utilized a stellar 2025 campaign at Arizona to cement his status as a premiere deep-third defender. Recording 77 tackles and 14 pass deflections, he displays a natural knack for locating the football and erasing vertical windows. While he must improve his tackling consistency against heavy-set blockers, his 4.48-speed and fluid hips solidify a Day 2 projection. After a smooth Senior Bowl showcasing improved diagnostic instincts, Smith profiles as a high-floor "centerfield" safety with the elite range required to lead a modern NFL secondary.

name: Daylen Everette
summary: Daylen Everette (6’1/190) operates as a cerebral boundary corner who anchored Georgia’s elite secondary throughout their 2025 run. This First-Team All-SEC selection excels in press-man coverage, deploying "patient hands" to neutralize vertical threats. While he lacks elite, "twitchy" recovery burst, his diagnostic skills and 82.5 PFF coverage grade make him a scheme-diverse asset for any NFL system. Following a strong Senior Bowl showing where he erased top-tier receivers in one-on-ones, Everette has solidified a late-first-round grade. He possesses the pro-ready technique and poise required to start immediately for a contending defense.

name: Harold Perkins
summary: Harold Perkins (6’1/235) remains a generational athletic specimen who returned to LSU in 2025 following a 2024 ACL injury. Shifting to a "Star" hybrid role, Perkins regained his 4.4-speed and "game-wrecking" burst, recording 8.0 sacks and 14.0 TFLs. While his thin frame raises concerns regarding his ability to stack-and-shed interior linemen, his elite pursuit range and bend off the edge make him a defensive coordinator’s dream. Currently projected as a mid-first-round pick, Perkins offers rare versatility to rush, cover, or spy, making him a franchise-altering asset for multiple NFL defensive fronts.

name: Michael Taaffe
summary: Michael Taaffe (6’0/190) represents a high-IQ "football junkie" who evolved from a walk-on into an All-SEC First Team leader at Texas. The 2025 Wuerffel Trophy winner combines elite diagnostic skills with a "nose for the football," recording 70 tackles and crucial interceptions. While he lacks the "freakish" athletic profile of top-tier safeties, his 4.52-speed and reliable tackling make him a "plug-and-play" asset. After a productive Shrine Bowl where he showcased elite communication skills, Taaffe offers third-round value with the high leadership and special teams floor needed to stabilize an NFL locker room.

name: Clay Patterson
summary: Clay Patterson (6’3/285) provides an "effort-first" interior presence who transitioned from Yale and UNLV to lead Stanford’s 2025 defensive line. Recording 4.0 sacks and 5.5 TFLs, Patterson utilizes a violent first-step and "slippery" hand usage to penetrate gaps. While he lacks the sheer mass to handle heavy NFL double-teams as a true nose, his versatility as a 3-technique makes him a valuable rotational asset. Following an active Senior Bowl week where he consistently collapsed the pocket, Patterson’s stock has risen into the Day 3 range as a high-value, high-motor interior depth piece.

name: Nick Singleton
summary: Nick Singleton (6’0/226) stands out as a "freak" athlete who combines 4.35-speed with elite play-strength, evidenced by his 655-pound squat. While he split carries in Penn State’s 2025 offense, Singleton remained a home-run threat, scoring 13 touchdowns and showcasing improved pass-blocking technique. Scouts note he can be "too patient" behind the line, but his ability to run through arm-tackles and erase pursuit angles makes him a second-round gem. After a successful draft-cycle showcasing his receiving floor, Singleton profiles as a "Jonathan Taylor-style" workhorse with the physical tools to headline a pro backfield.

name: Kaytron Allen
summary: Kaytron Allen (5’11/220) projects as a "violent" between-the-tackles runner who spearheaded Penn State’s ground game with 1,303 yards in 2025. A 2026 Senior Bowl standout, Allen impressed scouts with 18.6 MPH practice speeds and "piston-like" leg drive. While he lacks the "elite" top-end burners of his teammate Singleton, his 57 forced missed tackles highlight some of the best contact balance in the 2026 class. Currently trending as a mid-round value, Allen offers a high-floor, three-down bruiser profile with the functional mass to handle a 200-carry workload. He is the quintessential "finisher" for any offense.

name: Demond Claiborne
summary: Demond Claiborne (5’10/195) serves as a "shifty" all-purpose weapon who left Wake Forest as the program’s fourth all-time leading rusher. Recording 907 yards and 10 touchdowns in 2025, Claiborne excels in space, using elite short-area burst to turn check-downs into chunk plays. While his diminutive frame raises durability concerns for a full-time NFL workload, his 1,000+ all-purpose yards in consecutive seasons highlight his consistency. After showing out as a return specialist during the Shrine Bowl, Claiborne projects as a late-Day 3 value. He is a scheme-diverse "change-of-pace" back with game-breaking return potential.

name: Mikail Kamara
summary: Mikail Kamara (6’1/265) anchors Indiana’s historic 2025 defensive front as a "high-motor" disruptor. While his 2025 sack totals dipped, his 58 total pressures led the Big Ten, showcasing a relentless ability to collapse the pocket. Scouts noted his "violent" hand-usage and leverage-based power during a standout Senior Bowl week, where he consistently won against larger tackles. Despite being "undersized" for a traditional 5-technique, his diagnostic skills and "non-stop" pursuit solidify a second-round grade. Kamara provides high-floor, rotational edge-rusher value with the functional strength to set the edge and impact run games immediately.

name: Jack Endries
summary: Jack Endries (6’4/240) emerged as a "quarterback-friendly" tight end who thrived at Texas after transferring from Cal in 2025. A John Mackey Award semifinalist, Endries excels at finding soft spots in zone coverage, recording 93 yards against Texas A&M and a touchdown in the Citrus Bowl. While he lacks "elite" vertical speed to stretch the seams, his 11.1 YPC average and reliable hands make him a high-end red-zone target. After a refined Senior Bowl where he proved his utility as an in-line blocker, Endries projects as a mid-round value. He is a pro-ready "Y" prospect.

name: Joe Royer
summary: Joe Royer (6’5”, 250 lbs) brings NFL size with legitimate receiving polish after producing 50+ catches and 500+ yards in his final season. He was one of the more reliable tight ends during Senior Bowl week, consistently winning one-on-ones with route tempo and strong hands. Royer excels attacking zone coverage, finishing through contact, and working the seams, though he’s more smooth than explosive after the catch. Blocking effort is solid but not dominant. With steady production and an effective Senior Bowl showing, he profiles as a Day 2 tight end who can contribute early as a pass-game option.

name: C.J. Daniels
summary: C.J. Daniels (6’2”, 195 lbs) wins vertically, leveraging speed and ball tracking to generate chunk plays downfield. He posted 700+ receiving yards and multiple explosive touchdowns, routinely stretching coverage and winning contested catches along the boundary. Daniels flashes separation late in routes and shows confidence attacking the football, though physical press corners can disrupt his timing early. He lacks consistent yards-after-catch creation but profiles as a field-stretcher defenses must account for. While not a major award winner, his production and athletic profile give him mid-round appeal as a rotational outside receiver with upside in a vertical passing offense.

name: Drew Allar
