summary: Drew Allar (6’5”, 240 lbs) flashes every trait NFL teams look for in a prototype pocket passer, backed by 3,000+ passing yards and a strong touchdown-to-interception ratio. His arm strength jumps off the tape, particularly on deep outs and intermediate throws over the middle. Allar shows improved command of protections and progressions, earning All-Conference consideration, though pressure still speeds him up at times. Mobility is functional but not a featured part of his game. Teams will bet on tools, size, and trajectory, viewing him as a high-upside quarterback who fits best in a timing-based system.

name: DeMonte Capehart
summary: DeMonte Capehart (6’4”, 315 lbs) operates as a power interior presence capable of anchoring against the run and collapsing pockets. He logged 30+ tackles with several tackles for loss, showing flashes of dominance when his pad level stays low. Capehart generates push with raw strength but remains inconsistent finishing plays as a pass rusher. He doesn’t rack up sacks, yet his impact shows up in muddy pockets and disrupted run lanes. Without major postseason accolades, his value lies in projection. He profiles as an early-down rotational defensive tackle with upside if his hand usage and counters improve.

name: Malachi Lawrence
summary: Malachi Lawrence (6’4”, 255 lbs) flashes enticing edge traits, combining length, burst, and physicality while posting 6+ sacks and double-digit tackles for loss. He sets a firm edge against the run and shows closing speed when working in space. Lawrence’s pass-rush plan remains a work in progress, relying heavily on athleticism rather than sequencing. While not a Senior Bowl standout, his production and tools keep evaluators interested. He projects as a developmental edge rusher who can contribute early on passing downs, with starter potential if his technique and consistency continue trending upward.

name: Wesley Williams
summary: Wesley Williams (6’3”, 260 lbs) shows up on tape as an effort-driven edge defender with flashes of disruption, finishing the season with moderate sack production and steady pressure totals. He plays with good motor and functional power, occasionally winning with first-step quickness and leverage. Williams wasn’t a major postseason invite, and his lack of consistent production shows up against top competition. Refinement is needed with hand usage and rush counters. NFL teams will view him as a late-round or priority free agent prospect whose value lies in developmental upside and rotational depth along the defensive front.

name: Domani Jackson
summary: Domani Jackson (6’1”, 195 lbs) plays with confidence and competitiveness, allowing limited separation while contributing multiple pass breakups and interceptions over the season. He’s fluid in man coverage, comfortable in off-zone, and willing in run support. Jackson’s recruiting pedigree shows in his athletic traits, though he can be stressed by elite vertical speed if technique slips. While not a Senior Bowl participant, he earned All-Conference recognition and steady draft buzz. His profile fits a versatile defensive scheme, projecting as a potential Day 2 or early Day 3 corner with starter upside.

name: Seth McGowan
summary: Seth McGowan (5’11”, 215 lbs) runs with purpose, piling up 800+ rushing yards and multiple touchdowns as a physical, between-the-tackles presence. He shows good vision, contact balance, and decisiveness hitting downhill lanes, particularly in short-yardage situations. McGowan doesn’t bring home-run speed, but he consistently falls forward and wears down defenses. Receiving production is modest, and pass protection remains uneven. Without postseason accolades, his appeal is role-based. He profiles as a dependable rotational NFL back capable of handling early-down work and situational carries in a committee approach.

name: Tacario Davis
summary: Tacario Davis (6’4”, 195 lbs) turned heads throughout the pre-draft process, standing out at the Senior Bowl with his length, physicality, and ball disruption. He recorded multiple interceptions and double-digit pass breakups, using his reach to erase throwing windows in press and zone looks. Davis excels rerouting receivers but can struggle transitioning against quick cuts. Tackling effort is evident, though angles need refinement. His rare size-speed profile gives him strong draft appeal, projecting as a press-capable outside corner with clear starter upside in length-driven defensive schemes.

name: Zxavian Harris
summary: Zxavian Harris (6’3/305) contributed in Mississippi State’s interior rotation during 2025, adding tackles, TFLs, and pocket pressure across limited snaps. Quickness off the snap for his frame, active hands to disengage, and power to hold against doubles stood out when pad level remained low. Multi-alignment value (3-technique to nose) and short-burst motor offer developmental upside. Leverage issues appear when pad level rises against climbing blockers; pass-rush counters stay limited with little bend vs. quicker guards; stamina drops in longer series. Mid-to-late Day 3 projection (Round 5-7) in the 2026 NFL Draft as rotational depth with potential for snaps if technique and strength improve.

name: Hezekiah Masses
summary: Hezekiah Masses (5’11/185) appeared in California’s nickel and boundary packages in 2025, showing quick feet, competitive ball skills, and solid run support in rotational reps. Press technique at the line, mirroring underneath, and instincts in zone/match coverage showed promise. Athletic profile and competitive traits fit as a developmental corner with nickel/slot upside. Recovery speed and burst lag against vertical threats; tackling angles in open space remain inconsistent; technique lapses occur during coverage transitions. Day 3/UDFA projection in the 2026 NFL Draft with upside as depth corner or special teams contributor if strength is added and coverage details are refined.

name: Kevin Coleman Jr.
summary: Kevin Coleman Jr. (5’11/185) worked primarily in Missouri’s slot in 2025, displaying quick separation underneath, reliable hands, and yards after catch on slants/screens. Route nuance, acceleration out of breaks, and space creation appeared in limited production. Slot traits and return potential provide developmental upside. Size and contested-catch ability limit him against physical corners; deep-threat profile remains modest; press coverage at the line creates inconsistency. Day 3 projection (Round 5-7) in the 2026 NFL Draft with upside as rotational slot piece or special teams contributor if releases are refined and strength is added.

name: Kyle Louis
summary: Kyle Louis (6’2/230) saw rotational linebacker snaps at Pittsburgh in 2025, contributing solid range, tackling efficiency, and instincts in diagnosing plays. Run defense, blitz packages, and coverage situations benefited from his sideline-to-sideline traits and pursuit motor. Developmental off-ball linebacker with three-down potential. Physicality and shedding remain inconsistent against climbing blockers; slow reads and false steps occur in aggressive run fits; added functional strength and mass are needed to anchor in the box. Day 3 projection (Round 5-7) in the 2026 NFL Draft with upside as depth linebacker and special teams contributor if run-game technique improves and bulk is added.

name: Cade Klubnik
summary: Cade Klubnik (6’2/210) started at quarterback for Clemson in 2025, completing over 65% of passes for 3,000+ yards and 25+ touchdowns while adding rushing production. Arm strength, quick release, pocket poise, mobility to extend plays, and accuracy under pressure stood out. Dual-threat quarterback capable of attacking all levels and leading the offense effectively. Happy feet and hold-the-ball tendencies surface against pressure; aggressive decisions occur in tight windows; pre-snap processing can lag versus complex blitzes. Mid-to-late Day 2 projection (Round 3-5) in the 2026 NFL Draft with backup-to-starter potential in schemes that leverage arm talent and mobility.

name: Oscar Delp
summary: Oscar Delp (6’4/245) started at tight end for Georgia in 2025, contributing receptions in seam and red-zone roles alongside blocking effort on over 50% of snaps. Route nuance, leaping at the catch point, and versatility in-line/slot alignments appeared. Developmental move tight end with receiving traits and every-down value. Blocking technique and anchor remain inconsistent against power edges; height advantage is limited in contested situations; vertical speed to stretch seams is modest against safety help. Day 3 projection (Round 4-6) in the 2026 NFL Draft with upside as rotational TE2/TE3 if blocking hand placement is refined and strength is added.

name: Tim Keenan III
summary: Tim Keenan III (6’3/305) rotated in Alabama’s interior snaps in 2025, adding tackles, TFLs, and pocket pressure in run and pass phases. Quickness for size, active hands to disengage, and power to anchor against doubles stood out when pad level stayed low. Developmental 3-technique/nose tackle with multi-alignment value and high motor in short bursts. Leverage issues arise when pad level rises against climbing blockers; pass-rush counters are limited with little bend against quicker guards; stamina drops in extended reps. Day 3 projection (Round 5-7) in the 2026 NFL Draft with upside as rotational depth if technique is refined and strength is added.

name: Eric Rivers
summary: Eric Rivers (5’11”, 190 lbs) emerged as a dynamic slot weapon, leading his offense with 80+ receptions and over 1,000 receiving yards, consistently creating separation underneath and after the catch. Rivers excels with short-area quickness, route tempo, and feel versus zone coverage, making him a reliable chain mover. He adds value on jet motion and screens, averaging strong yards after contact for his size. While not a Senior Bowl participant, his production earned All-Conference honors. Limited catch radius and play strength cap his ceiling, but he projects as a high-floor slot receiver with early rotational value.

name: DeShon Singleton
summary: DeShon Singleton (6’0”, 230 lbs) anchors the defense as a physical, downhill linebacker who filled the stat sheet with 100+ tackles, double-digit tackles for loss, and multiple sacks. He diagnoses quickly, triggers downhill with force, and shows leadership as the communicator in the front seven. Singleton isn’t a rangy coverage linebacker and can be stressed by speed in space, but his instincts and tackling reliability stand out. He earned First-Team All-Conference recognition and flashed well in postseason all-star practices. Projects as a Day 3 linebacker with special teams value and early-down defensive utility.

name: Ted Hurst
summary: Ted Hurst (6’4”, 275 lbs) plays with effort and leverage along the defensive front, producing 5+ sacks and steady pressure totals while aligning inside and on the edge. Hurst wins with motor, hand strength, and gap discipline rather than burst, consistently disrupting run lanes. He wasn’t a Senior Bowl invitee, but his tape shows reliability and toughness against quality competition. Athletic ceiling is modest, limiting his upside as a primary rusher. Still, his versatility and physical play style make him a viable rotational defensive lineman who can contribute early in run-heavy situations.

name: TJ Hall
summary: TJ Hall (6’2”, 200 lbs) offers intriguing size-speed traits at cornerback, pairing length with competitive coverage skills. He finished the season with multiple interceptions and double-digit pass breakups, showing comfort in press-man and zone-match looks. Hall tracks the ball well and plays with confidence at the catch point, though his footwork can get loose against sharp route runners. He wasn’t a Senior Bowl standout, but his production earned All-Conference mention. With refinement in technique and consistency, Hall projects as a developmental outside corner with starting upside in man-heavy schemes.

name: David Oke
summary: David Oke (6’5”, 310 lbs) brings massive interior presence, functioning as a true space-eater with 30+ tackles and several tackles for loss while commanding double teams. Oke’s value lies in anchoring against the run, controlling gaps, and allowing linebackers to flow freely. Pass-rush production is limited, and his get-off remains average, but his strength and length are undeniable. He did not participate in postseason all-star events, keeping his profile quieter. NFL teams will view him as a rotational nose or one-tech defensive tackle best suited for early downs and short-yardage packages.

name: Josh Cameron
summary: Josh Cameron (6’1”, 205 lbs) produced as a dependable perimeter receiver, recording 700+ yards and multiple touchdowns while serving as a go-to option on intermediate routes. He plays with strong hands, good body control, and toughness over the middle, consistently finishing through contact. Cameron isn’t a burner, but he creates separation with route nuance and timing. While lacking major awards or Senior Bowl exposure, his steady production stands out. He projects as a depth wide receiver who can contribute on third downs and special teams, with upside as a reliable WR3 or WR4.

name: Jordan van den Berg
summary: Jordan van den Berg (6’4”, 295 lbs) flashes interior disruption with multiple sacks and tackles for loss, showing quick hands and good leverage for his size. He penetrates effectively on stunts and twists, collapsing pockets when his timing is right. Van den Berg can struggle holding up against double teams and needs more consistency anchoring versus the run. He wasn’t a Senior Bowl headliner, but his athletic interior profile draws interest. With refinement, he projects as a rotational 3-tech defensive tackle capable of contributing in pass-rush packages and sub fronts.

name: Xavier Scott
summary: Xavier Scott (5’10”, 200 lbs) brings explosiveness and versatility as a running back, totaling 900+ all-purpose yards with contributions as a rusher and receiver. He shows excellent lateral agility, burst through creases, and value on third downs. Scott creates mismatches in space but lacks ideal size for sustained interior work and can be inconsistent in pass protection. While not a postseason award winner, his production and versatility stand out. He profiles as a change-of-pace NFL back with receiving upside, best suited for a committee role that maximizes his space and matchup ability.

name: Skyler Gill-Howard
summary: Skyler Gill-Howard brings a competitive, assignment-sound profile that NFL teams tend to value more than the box score alone. He plays with good processing speed, disciplined eyes, and consistent effort snap to snap, allowing him to stay within structure and limit explosive breakdowns. Gill-Howard doesn’t rely on elite traits, but his reliability, toughness, and football IQ show up on tape, particularly in situational and complementary roles. He projects as a Day 3 selection (Rounds 5–7) or priority free agent. Early in his career, he profiles as a special teams contributor and rotational depth piece, with the upside to earn defensive snaps as trust and reps accumulate.

name: Bishop Fitzgerald
summary: Bishop Fitzgerald (6’3”, 315 lbs) profiles as a wide-bodied interior lineman built to control space and eat snaps, finishing the year with 30+ tackles and multiple tackles for loss. He plays with heavy hands, good anchor strength, and consistently holds ground against double teams. Fitzgerald isn’t a penetrator by nature, offering limited pass-rush juice, but his ability to clog lanes shows up on early downs. He earned All-Conference honorable mention for his consistency. NFL teams will view him as a rotational nose or one-tech who can stabilize the interior and contribute in short-yardage situations.

name: Louis Moore
summary: Louis Moore (6’0”, 190 lbs) brings physicality and competitiveness to the secondary, producing 70+ tackles, double-digit pass breakups, and multiple interceptions. He plays with confidence in man coverage and isn’t shy about triggering downhill in run support. Moore’s instincts and toughness stand out, though he can be tested vertically by elite speed. He flashed well in postseason practices, boosting his stock late in the cycle. Without major awards, his appeal comes from reliability and edge. He projects as a Day 3 defensive back with special teams value and potential as a nickel or depth safety.

name: Bryce Lance
summary: Bryce Lance (6’3”, 215 lbs) operates as a smooth, possession-oriented wide receiver who consistently moves the chains, finishing with 60+ receptions and 800+ yards. He wins with route detail, body control, and strong hands in traffic, particularly on intermediate patterns. Lance lacks top-end speed, limiting his vertical threat, but he compensates with timing and physicality. He earned Second-Team All-Conference honors and served as a quarterback-friendly target throughout the season. His profile fits a reliable WR3/WR4 role at the next level, offering early contribution in structured passing attacks.

name: Jaden Greathouse
summary: Jaden Greathouse (6’2”, 210 lbs) brings a pro-ready frame and physical receiving style, posting 700+ yards and multiple touchdowns while frequently drawing top coverage. He excels at shielding defenders, winning contested catches, and working the middle of the field. Greathouse plays with confidence and toughness but can struggle to separate consistently against quick, technical corners. He did not appear in a Senior Bowl setting, but his production earned All-Conference recognition. Teams will value his reliability and size, projecting him as a boundary receiver who can contribute early in red-zone and possession roles.

name: Trey Moore
summary: Trey Moore (6’3”, 255 lbs) stands out as a productive edge rusher, recording 8+ sacks and double-digit tackles for loss while consistently pressuring quarterbacks. He shows good first-step quickness, active hands, and the ability to convert speed to power. Moore flashed during Senior Bowl practices, winning one-on-one reps and elevating his draft stock. While he can be neutralized by strong tackles when his timing is off, his motor runs hot. He earned First-Team All-Conference honors and projects as a Day 2 or early Day 3 edge with rotational upside and pass-rush value.

name: Brent Austin
summary: Brent Austin (6’1”, 225 lbs) plays the linebacker position with urgency and physicality, racking up 90+ tackles, multiple tackles for loss, and forced turnovers. He diagnoses quickly, fills gaps decisively, and shows leadership directing traffic pre-snap. Coverage range is serviceable but not a strength, particularly against athletic tight ends. Austin earned All-Conference honors for his production and consistency. While he wasn’t a Senior Bowl invitee, his tape reflects reliability. He projects as a Day 3 linebacker with early special teams impact and rotational value in run-heavy defensive packages.

name: Lander Barton
summary: Lander Barton (6’4”, 235 lbs) offers versatility as a modern linebacker, combining length with range to post 80+ tackles, sacks, and pass breakups. He moves fluidly in space, showing comfort dropping into coverage while still contributing as a blitzer. Barton’s play strength remains a developmental area, particularly when taking on blocks inside. He earned All-Conference recognition and flashed during postseason evaluations. His skill set fits today’s sub-package-heavy NFL, projecting as a hybrid linebacker who can contribute on passing downs early and grow into a three-down role with added strength.

name: J'Mari Taylor
summary: J’Mari Taylor (5’10”, 175 lbs) brings explosive speed and big-play ability, averaging over 17 yards per catch with multiple long touchdowns. He threatens defenses vertically and horizontally, showing dangerous acceleration with the ball in his hands. Taylor’s size limits his effectiveness in contested situations, and physical coverage can disrupt his routes. While he lacks postseason accolades, his production and athletic profile stand out. NFL teams will view him as a developmental deep threat and gadget weapon who can contribute on special teams and manufactured touches while expanding his role offensively.

name: Jeff Caldwell
summary: Jeff Caldwell (6’2/195 est.) contributed as a rotational wide receiver for Cincinnati in 2025, showing reliable hands, intermediate separation, and yards after catch on slants/screens. Route nuance and body control appeared in limited production. Developmental slot/outside receiver with dependable traits. Size aids contested-catch situations; production remains modest; press coverage at the line creates inconsistency. Day 3/UDFA projection in the 2026 NFL Draft with upside as depth piece or special teams contributor if releases are refined and strength is added.

name: Caden Curry
summary: Caden Curry (6’3/250 est.) rotated on Ohio State’s edge in 2025, adding tackles, TFLs, and pressures with quick first step and power bull rush. Versatile alignment options and high motor showed in pass-rush and run-defense snaps. Developmental edge with starter traits if strength and technique improve. Bend and corner speed remain average vs. quicker tackles; pass-rush plan is power-heavy with limited counters; leverage issues occur when pad level rises. Mid-to-late Day 3 projection (Round 5-7) in the 2026 NFL Draft with upside as rotational disruptor in schemes that value motor and power.

name: Red Murdock
summary: Red Murdock (6’2/230 est.) started at linebacker for Buffalo in 2025, contributing solid range, tackling efficiency, and instincts in run defense and coverage. Sideline-to-sideline traits and pursuit motor appeared in rotational snaps. Developmental off-ball linebacker with three-down potential. Physicality and shedding remain inconsistent against climbing blockers; slow reads and false steps occur in aggressive run fits; added strength and mass are needed to anchor in the box. Day 3 projection (Round 5-7) in the 2026 NFL Draft with upside as depth linebacker and special teams contributor if run-game technique improves.

name: Max Llewellyn

name: Sam Roush
summary: Sam Roush (6’5/250) stands out as the premiere "pure blocker" of the 2026 class, earning Lance Zierlein’s praise for his elite "drive-blocking" technique at Stanford. While he lacks elite vertical burners to stretch the deep third, his ability to displace defenders in the run game and secure difficult catches in traffic is unmatched. Roush profiles as a high-value mid-round pick with immediate Super Bowl-contributing utility.

name: Le'Veon Moss
summary: Le'Veon Moss (5’11/210) remains a "violence-first" runner who overcame significant injuries to lead Texas A&M’s ground game in 2025. name: Mike Washington Jr.
summary: Mike Washington Jr. (6’2/225) represents a "breakout" physical specimen who recorded 1,070 yards and 9 touchdowns for Arkansas in 2025. This bigger-bodied back combines elite vision with a "Rhamondre Stevenson-style" ability to make defenders miss despite his imposing frame. While fumbles have been a developmental hurdle, his career-high 6.4 yards per carry and productive receiving floor highlight true three-down potential. After impressing in Mobile with his quick-decision making and "fall-forward" power, Washington projects as a fourth-round gem. He offers the functional mass and motor to handle a heavy professional workload from Week 1.

name: Nadame Tucker
summary: Nadame Tucker (6’3/250) provides elite pass-rush efficiency, having recorded 14 sacks and a staggering 93.3 PFF grade for Western Michigan in 2025. This relentless edge-penetrator utilizes "violent" hand-usage and a sophisticated array of counters to consistently harass quarterbacks. While his "one-year wonder" status and older age (turning 26) have sparked some draft-board debate, his dominant Senior Bowl week silenced critics regarding his level of competition. Currently vaulting into Day 2 consideration, Tucker offers the high-motor, disruptive traits required for an immediate situational pass-rush role. He is the class’s premier sleeper edge-rusher.

name: Keyron Crawford
summary: Keyron Crawford (6’4/255) emerges as a "fast-riser" who spearheaded Auburn’s pass rush with 43 pressures and a formidable "swipe-and-chop" move. While he occasionally struggles to hold the point of attack against heavier "power" blockers, his elite quickness and hand-speed were the talk of Senior Bowl one-on-ones. Projected as a third-round selection, Crawford possesses the rare athletic ceiling and "twitch" to develop into a consistent double-digit sack artist.

name: Zavion Thomas
summary: Zavion Thomas (5’10/192) functions as a "human joystick" who utilized his 4.32-speed to revitalize LSU’s vertical and return games in 2025. While his diminutive frame limits his red-zone utility, his vision as a return specialist and versatility to align in the slot make him a primary gadget weapon. Following a productive Senior Bowl showing, Thomas profiles as a Day 3 value. He is the quintessential "chain-mover" for creative offensive coordinators in 2026.

This Detroit native combines brute interior strength with surprisingly nimble footwork, proving his effectiveness as both a run-stuffer and gap-penetrator. After a "dominant" Senior Bowl performance that Dane Brugler suggests puts him in the First-Round conversation, Benny’s stock is at an all-time high. He possesses the heavy hands and "pro-ready" anchor required to neutralize NFL double-teams. Benny is the premiere interior defensive cornerstone of the 2026 draft cycle.

Projected as a mid-round selection, Dixon offers the rare frame and recovery speed to neutralize physical NFL targets. He is a high-floor corner prospect.

Wilson earned All-Conference recognition and steady draft buzz. Kite offers the high-end movement skills and zone-scheme IQ needed to stabilize a pro secondary. He is a high-upside developmental prospect for 2026.

summary: Logan Fano (6’4/245) functions as a relentless edge-rusher who successfully navigated a third career ACL recovery to anchor Utah’s 2025 defensive line. While his medical history remains a primary "minefield" for NFL evaluators, his high-IQ diagnostic skills and 85.0 PFF run-defense grade suggest a pro-ready floor. Currently projected as a Day 3 sleeper, Fano possesses the rare mental toughness and "slippery" pass-rush traits to develop into a consistent situational contributor in any NFL front.

While his significant back and shoulder medical history limits his ceiling to a "gadget" backup role, his 4.38-speed and improved "post-pressure" poise impressed scouts during the recent showcase circuit. Currently trending toward a late-round selection, Daniels offers the unique high-ceiling versatility to revolutionize a creative NFL offensive system.

name: Lewis Bond

He is a premier vertical weapon for the 2026 draft.

name: J.Michael Sturdivant
summary: J.Michael Sturdivant (6’3/205) operates as a physically dominant boundary target who utilizes a massive catch radius to "envelop" smaller NFL-caliber corners. This lean, long-striding athlete thrives in the red zone, leveraging his track-and-field background to turn 50-50 balls into high-percentage receptions. While he must improve his initial burst off the line and route-tree nuances, his 20+ MPH play speed and "reliable" possession numbers solidify a late Day 2 grade. Sturdivant offers the elite high-pointing ability and "pro-ready" frame required for a primary goal-line fade target. He is a unique high-ceiling weapon for a pro offense.

name: Devin Moore
summary: Devin Moore (5’11/185 est.) contributed in Florida’s secondary rotation in 2025, showing quick feet, competitive ball skills, and solid run support in nickel and boundary snaps. Press technique at the line, mirroring underneath, and instincts in zone/match coverage appeared in limited production. Developmental corner with nickel/slot upside. Recovery speed and burst lag against vertical threats; tackling angles in open space remain inconsistent; technique lapses occur during transitions. Day 3/UDFA projection in the 2026 NFL Draft with upside as depth corner or special teams contributor if strength is added and coverage details are refined.

name: Cameron Ball
summary: Cameron Ball (6’3/290 est.) rotated in Arkansas’ interior snaps in 2025, adding tackles, TFLs, and pocket pressure in run and pass phases. Quickness for size, active hands to disengage, and power to anchor against doubles stood out when pad level stayed low. Developmental 3-technique/nose tackle with multi-alignment value and high motor in short bursts. Leverage issues arise when pad level rises against climbing blockers; pass-rush counters are limited with little bend against quicker guards; stamina drops in extended reps. Day 3 projection (Round 5-7) in the 2026 NFL Draft with upside as rotational depth if technique is refined and strength is added.

name: Jaydn Ott
summary: Jaydn Ott (6’0/210) functions as a patient, vision-first runner who navigated a complex 2025 transition to Oklahoma after three productive years at Cal. This "slasher-style" back excels in gap-scheme systems, utilizing subtle lateral agility and elite footwork to manipulate interior lanes. While scouts note he lacks the elite, track-star gear to consistently turn the corner against NFL speed, his refined pass-protection anchor and reliable hands offer three-down utility. Following a solid Senior Bowl week that highlighted his high-IQ diagnostic skills, Ott projects as a Day 2 value. He is the quintessential "rhythm" back for any pro-style offense.

name: Deven Eastern
summary: Deven Eastern (6’6/320) provides a massive, high-ceiling presence on the interior, capping his Minnesota career with a career-high 499 snaps and 38 tackles in 2025. This "long-limbed" disruptor utilizes rare reach and a relentless motor to reset the line of scrimmage and collapse pocket integrity. While his pass-rush arsenal remains power-centric with limited lateral twitch, his ability to stack-and-shed double teams makes him a scheme-diverse asset. After a strong Senior Bowl where he showcased elite "knock-back" strength, Eastern’s stock has risen into the Day 3 conversation. He is a pro-ready anchor with immediate rotational value.

name: Noah Thomas
summary: Noah Thomas (6’6/200) stands out as a "towering" boundary weapon who utilized a 2025 transfer to Georgia to showcase elite red-zone utility. This long-striding target excels at high-pointing the football, leveraging his massive catch radius to "neutralize" smaller corners in contested-catch scenarios. While he lacks the "explosive" short-area twitch of a primary separator, his 15.9 yards-per-reception average and improved route-stems suggest a high-floor possession role. Following a productive draft cycle that highlighted his reliable hands, Thomas projects as a mid-round gem. He offers the prototypical "above-the-rim" traits needed for an NFL "X" receiver role.

name: Peyton Bowen
summary: Peyton Bowen (6’0/201) operates as a high-IQ "centerfield" safety who utilized a productive 2025 junior campaign to cement his status as a premier post-defender. This former five-star recruit combines elite 4.4-speed with "telepathic" diagnostic instincts, recording over 70 career tackles and multiple special-teams blocks. While he must continue adding functional mass to consistently reroute physical NFL tight ends, his range and "click-and-close" agility make him a defensive coordinator’s dream. Currently trending as a Day 2 selection, Bowen offers the rare versatility to play single-high or drop into the nickel. He is a franchise-altering secondary general.

name: Jake Retzlaff
summary: Jake Retzlaff (6’1/205) emerged as the "comeback story" of 2025, leading Tulane to a 10-win season after a high-profile transfer from BYU. This "gunslinger-style" commander operates with an aggressive, vertical-first mentality, showcasing the arm talent to drive the ball into intermediate windows under heavy pressure. While his "risk-taker" approach leads to occasional turnover-worthy plays, his 22 touchdowns and elite "off-platform" creativity have caught the attention of NFL evaluators. Following a refined Senior Bowl showcasing improved decision-making, Retzlaff projects as a mid-round value. He possesses the raw "cool" and grit required for a professional backup role.

name: Hank Beatty
summary: Hank Beatty (5’11/185) represents a "Swiss Army Knife" weapon who made history in 2025 as the only player with passing, rushing, receiving, and return touchdowns. This high-IQ technician excels in the slot, utilizing "pro-ready" route savvy and elite short-area burst to turn shallow crossers into chunk gains. While his diminutive frame limits his boundary utility, his 1,123 all-purpose yards and record-breaking punt-return ability solidify a Day 3 grade. After a standout Senior Bowl where he proved his reliability as a "chain-mover," Beatty offers the scheme-diverse utility needed for any creative NFL offensive system in 2026.

name: Brandon Cleveland
summary: Brandon Cleveland (6’4/315) functions as a "violent" interior presence who anchored NC State’s 2025 front with 36 tackles and 7.0 TFLs. This former baseball standout utilizes "heavy hands" and elite upper-body strength to displace interior linemen and erase running lanes. While he isn't a "finesse" pass-rusher, his ability to "forklift" centers off their spots creates consistent chaos in the pocket. Following an active Senior Bowl week where he consistently held the point against double-teams, Cleveland’s stock has solidified in the fourth-round range. He is a high-floor, run-stuffing specialist with the mass to start immediately.

name: Dane Key
summary: Dane Key (6’3/210) stands as a "refined" boundary target who spearheaded Nebraska’s 2025 vertical attack after transferring from Kentucky. This "muscular" possession weapon excels at shielding defenders with his frame, utilizing elite hand-eye coordination to secure difficult catches in tight windows. While he lacks the "elite" separation speed of a top-tier burner, his savvy release package and "professional" approach to pattern-matching make him a high-floor prospect. Projected as a mid-round value, Key offers the reliable "chain-moving" utility and blocking prowess required for a WR2 role. He is the quintessential "stabilizer" for a pro offense.

name: De'Zhaun Stribling
summary: De’Zhaun Stribling (6’2/210) provides an "explosive" deep-threat profile, having recorded 811 yards and 6 touchdowns for Ole Miss during a standout 2025 campaign. This Hawaii native combines long, gazelle-like strides with the body control needed to win "50-50" balls along the boundary. While he occasionally struggles with focus-drops, his 14.7 yards-per-catch average and "catch-to-attack" mentality highlight a high-end WR2 ceiling. After a productive Senior Bowl showcasing his ability to stack elite corners, Stribling has vaulted into the Day 2 conversation. He is a premier vertical weapon with the twitch to dominate pro secondaries.

summary: Dillon Bell (6’1/210 est.) transitioned to a rotational wide receiver role for Georgia in 2025 after prior snaps at tight end, showing reliable hands, intermediate separation, and yards after catch on slants/screens. Size aids contested-catch situations; production remains modest; press coverage at the line creates inconsistency. Day 3/UDFA projection in the 2026 NFL Draft with upside as depth piece or special teams contributor if releases are refined and strength is added.
